en_second_half: with aches, cramps, rheumatisms, and every species of ailment that can afflict the old and the feeble."
en_results: with aches and pains, and a general feeling of being unwell. She could not help but laugh at the memory
en_results_raw: with aches and pains, and a general feeling of being unwell. She could not help but laugh at the memory of her brother-in-law's attempts to persuade her to wear such a garment, and the image of him wrapped up in a flannel waistcoat, looking like a walking bundle of wool, was too ridiculous to contemplate. "I am afraid, Sir John," she said, trying to compose herself, "that I must decline your offer. I fear I should be more likely to take a chill from wearing such a thing, than to be preserved from one by it." Sir John looked at her with a mixture of surprise and amusement, and she could tell that he was struggling not to laugh at her expense. "Well, my dear Marianne," he said, "I suppose I must content myself with the knowledge that you are at least warm in your refusal, even if you will not be warm in a flannel waistcoat." He smiled at her, and she could not help but smile back, feeling a sense of relief that the subject had been dropped, and that she was not going to be plagued with the offer of a flannel waistcoat again.

en_results: from the firm of solicitors which had, for many years, transacted all the legal business of the family. It
en_results_raw: from the firm of solicitors which had, for many years, transacted all the legal business of the family. It was addressed to the master of the house, and the butler, who had brought it in, handed it to him with the respect due to his position. The master, however, merely glanced at the envelope, and, seeing that it was not a letter of a private nature, handed it to his secretary, who was seated at the table with him. The secretary, having opened the envelope, took out the contents, and, after glancing over them, handed them to his employer, saying, "It is from the solicitors, sir. They have written to inform you that the will of your late uncle has been proved, and that the reading of it will take place at their office on Thursday next." The master of the house looked up from his breakfast, and, after a moment's consideration, said, "I must be present at the reading of the will. I will go up to town tomorrow, and will be at the solicitors' office on Thursday, at the time appointed." The secretary made a note of this in his pocket-book, and the master of the house resumed his breakfast, and the conversation turned upon other matters.

en_results_raw: one circumstance, I fear, is of so much weight, that it ought to outweigh all the rest, and that is, the want of a sufficient fortune on the part of the young man. I do not mean to say, that a woman of sense and education should marry a man merely for his fortune; but I do say, that a young couple, with small means, and no connections, must be very prudent, and very careful, in their outset in life, or they will soon find themselves in difficulties, from which it will be hard to extricate themselves. I have known many instances of young people, who have married with very little, and have been very happy, but they have always been prudent, and careful, and have known how to make the most of what they had. But I fear, that this young man, is not of that description; he is very thoughtless, and very extravagant, and I fear, that he will soon run through, what little he has, and then, what will become of his wife, and his children? I do not wish to be a prophet of evil, but I fear, that this marriage, will not turn out well.

She could say no more; her feelings were too strong. She turned away, and walked across the room; and too much agitated to be capable of speaking when Mr. Knightley came in, Jane was obliged to be her advocate; and not without the suspicion of having some influence in the request, was able to persuade her to sit down and be no longer a prey to such feelings. Hay dolor, hay sufrimiento, hay pérdida. Y yo, que me creía tan fuerte, tan invencible, me doy cuenta de que soy débil, que soy vulnerable. Pero a pesar de todo, no puedo dejar de recordar aquellos momentos, aquellos momentos de pureza, de inocencia, de felicidad. Porque aunque la vida sea dura, aunque sea cruel, también es hermosa, también es preciosa. Y yo, que he vivido, que he sufrido, que he perdido, puedo decir que la vida es un regalo, un regalo que debemos apreciar, que debemos disfrutar, cada momento, cada segundo, cada instante.

en_results_raw: She had never been so thoroughly disappointed in her expectations from any one, as she was in those of Mr. Darcy; and yet she had not been so very much surprised. She had expected to meet a proud and disagreeable man, and he had not at all exceeded her expectations. But still she had not expected that his reserve would be so marked, or his manners so little pleasing. She had thought that, though he might be proud, he would be proud of his family, and wish to recommend himself to her notice by every means; but it seemed that he was not proud enough, or not sufficiently aware of his own importance, to be so anxious to make a favourable impression. She was very much vexed, and began to think that she had been mistaken in her opinion of him, and that he was not the agreeable man she had supposed him to be. She was also a little angry with herself for having been so much deceived, and for having allowed herself to be so much pleased with the idea of his being in love with her. She was determined to be more cautious in future, and not to allow herself to be so easily imposed upon by a handsome face and a charming smile.

Elonor's words were laced with a soothing calmness, but beneath them, a subtle undercurrent of curiosity had begun to stir. She had always known her sister to be a private person, but this newfound secrecy was beginning to unsettle her. As she watched her brother's expression, a mix of emotions swirled across his face, like the gentle lapping of waves against the shore. His eyes, usually bright and carefree, now seemed to hold a deep sadness, a sense of longing that Elonor couldn't quite place. She felt an overwhelming urge to reach out, to comfort him, to tell him that everything would be alright, but something held her back. Perhaps it was the uncertainty that had been growing inside her, a feeling that her sister's secrets were only the tip of a much larger iceberg, one that threatened to disrupt the delicate balance of their lives.

Something, either in his appearance, or in his manner, had so strongly reminded her of some one, that she could not immediately say who, it was not the person herself, yet before the end of another day, she was frequently fancying that Captain Brandon was very like him altogether; and, though she would not have mentioned this idea in her wildest fancies, before the middle of the day after, she was so firmly persuaded of its truth, as to take notice to Mrs. Dashwood of the circumstance. "I have found out who it is," said she, "that Captain Brandon is so like. It is Mr. Willoughby; I am sure of it. I have been thinking of it all this morning, and I am quite sure of it. I am very glad I recollected it." Mrs. Dashwood was very much surprised, as might be expected; and though she would not venture to assert the resemblance, yet she did not by any means think it impossible. "I should not be at all astonished," said she, "if you were to find a great many points of similitude between them. They are both very handsome men; and there is a certain air of gentility in their address, which is very much alike." "But it is not that," said Marianne, "it is not that at all. It is a certain look, a certain way of thinking, that is so exactly alike, that I am perfectly convinced of it. I am very glad I have found it out." Mrs. Dashwood was very much pleased to see her so happy, and so much pleased with herself, and she did not by any means discourage her from fancying as much as she pleased; though she could not help thinking, that it was a great pity, she should have such a fancy; for she was very much afraid, that Captain Brandon was not at all likely to be married; and she was very much afraid, that Mr. Willoughby was not at all likely to be married neither. She was very much afraid, that they were both very much too old to be married; and she was very much afraid, that they were both very much too proud to be married. She was very much afraid, that they would both die old bachelors; and she was very much afraid, that Marianne would be very much disappointed, when she found it out. But she did not say any thing, and Marianne went on fancying, and went on talking, and went on thinking, and went on believing, that Captain Brandon was very much like Mr. Willoughby, and that she was very much in love with him.

en_first_half: "His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister—but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of
en_second_half: my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self–reproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."
en_results: her sister. I am happy to have this opportunity of speaking my mind to you, and of endeavouring to prevent the continuance of an intimacy which I have long seen with such apprehension. es_first_half: —Ahora puede ver cómo es su carácter: derrochador, licencioso, y peor aún que eso. Sabiéndolo, como yo lo he sabido desde hace ya muchas semanas, imagínese lo que debo haber sentido al ver a su hermana tan afecta a él como siempre, y cuando se me aseguró que iba a casarse con él; imagínese lo que habré sentido pensando en todas ustedes. Cuando vine a verla la semana pasada y la encontré sola, estaba decidido a saber la verdad, aunque aún indeciso en cuanto a qué hacer cuando la supiera. Mi comportamiento debe haberle extrañado, pero ahora lo entenderá. Tener que verlas a todas ustedes engañadas en esa forma; ver a su hermana... pero, ¿qué podía hacer? No tenía esperanza alguna de intervenir con éxito; y en ocasiones pensaba que su hermana aún podía mantener suficiente influencia sobre él para recuperarlo. Pero tras un trato tan ignominioso, ¿quién sabe cuáles serían sus intenciones hacia ella? Cualesquiera hayan sido, sin embargo, puede que ahora ella se sienta agradecida de su situación, y sin duda más adelante lo estará, cuando la compare con la de mi pobre Eliza, cuando
es_second_half: piense en la situación miserable y desesperada de esta pobre niña y se la imagine con un afecto tan fuerte por él, tan fuerte como el que ella misma le tiene, y con un espíritu atormentado por las autorrecriminaciones, que la acompañarán durante toda su vida. Con toda seguridad esta comparación le servirá de algo. Sentirá que sus propios sufrimientos no son nada. No provienen de una mala conducta y no pueden traerle desgracia. Al contrario, deberán hacer que en cada uno de sus amigos aumente la amistad hacia ella. La preocupación por su desdicha y el respeto por la entereza que subyace a ella deberán reforzar todos los afectos. Utilice, sin embargo, su propia discreción para comunicarle lo que le he contado. Usted debe saber mejor qué efecto tendrá; y si no hubiera creído muy seriamente y desde el fondo de mi corazón que pudiera serle de alguna utilidad, que pudiera aliviar sus padecimientos, no me habría permitido perturbarla con este relato de las aflicciones que ha debido sufrir mi familia, una narración con la cual podría sospecharse que intento enaltecerme a costa de los demás.

She respected her opinion so far as to be influenced by it, and to consider her feelings in the arrangement of the marriage, as the first wish of her heart. Her mother had ever been an object of such tender affection and reverence to Marianne, that she would not have grieved at all, had she believed the event to be the happiest of her life; and every scheme of felicity which Mrs. Dashwood had laid down for her daughter, was such as she herself would have most warmly adopted. But she had a persuasion that a very different scheme would have contributed most to the happiness of both. Marianne was to be married from home, and her mother's wishes were all in favour of a very grand style of living; but as she had received no inheritance from her father, who had lived to be nearly eighty, and had been so totally regardless of his daughter's interest in the disposal of his property, as to leave his estate from his only child, it was necessary for them to plan their future residence according to the fortune which Mr. Dashwood had in his power to give his wife, and in that, it was impossible for them to aspire at the style of living which her taste and knowledge of the world would have preferred. But though this had been a disappointment to her, she had not been very much grieved at it; for she had always considered that the happiness of a marriage depended entirely on the disposition of the parties, and the marriage of her sister was such as gave her the most sincere pleasure. He was a tall, thin man, with a pale face, and a very formal bow, and he began to talk in a low, measured tone, about the weather, and the state of the roads, and the news of the day, in a way that was meant to be very interesting, but was in reality, very dull and uninteresting. Elionor, who had been expecting some one of more consequence, was rather disappointed, and she listened to him with a mixture of politeness and indifference, while she was thinking of the business that she had been interrupted in, and wondering when she should be able to conclude it. The gentleman, whose name was Mr. Smith, seemed to be a very self-important person, and he talked a great deal about himself, and his own affairs, without seeming to be aware, that he was not particularly interesting to his hearer. Elionor, who was a very sensible girl, and not at all disposed to be taken in by his pretensions, listened to him with a calm and composed air, and replied to his observations, with a politeness, that was just sufficient to keep up the conversation, without seeming to be particularly interested in it.

I offered immediately, as soon as my mother related the affair to me, to talk to him myself, and dissuade him from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing, for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it till after the
en_second_half: breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you know, to interfere. But had I been informed of it a few hours earlier—I think it is most probable—that something might have been hit on. I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very strong light. 'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help thinking, in short, that means might have been found. But now it is all too late. He must be starved, you know;—that is certain; absolutely starved."
